climbs.name: Two Piece and a Biscuit
climbs.fa: Hagen Telg, Andrew Sykes, Jason Halladay

content.description: Short, grungy and a bit vegetated wide crack just right of Linter Hands in the small alcove. Surprisingly tricky finger crack to get started up to some gnarled roots before the wide climbing. Dig in (or stem!) the wide crack corner to the top.
content.protection: .5 camalot to #2 camalot, #4 through #6 camalots. Two bolt anchor with chain.
content.location: Right of Linter Hands in the small alcove.

content.description: A really cool, solid jamming route to a bouldery finish at the double "tuning fork" cracks.    Scramble up the gully to get on top of the block to the left. Reach across to place a #4 camalot and pull over to the crack and a tiny horizontal edge. Big hands to steep hand jamming goes up to the fork. Take the left fork, place high gear and make moves up both cracks to some good holds and a mantle up to the anchor.
content.protection: Camalots. Single #4, and red C3. Doubles (or singles, it's short) in #1 to #3. Green and purple link cam. An RP might protect the crux well but haven't tried it.
content.location: On the left side of the area. The forking cracks up high are obvious.

content.description: Never heard of a Wolperting? Me neither. Until this route. Enjoyable climbing in a nice corner of good rock on the left side of the area. Stem and layback your way up the wavy, thin hands corner on a miraculous adventure to the anchor.
content.protection: Camalots. #0.75 to #2s. #0.3 to #0.5 for the last bit.
content.location: The dark, quality rock corner on the left side of The Hinterlands. The two wavy bulges are obvious.

climbs.name: Mars Crack
climbs.fa: Cody Scarpella; EB: J. Smith and A. Miller

content.description: A very good but very hard finger crack. Starts in a nice textured finger crack and then the feet get really sparse.
content.protection: lots of 0.3 to 0.5. The fewer pieces you place, the more likely you will send.  Balance this with staying safe, please.
content.location: Just right of the wide "Anal Intruder".

climbs.name: Linter Hands
climbs.fa: Andrew Sykes, Jason Halladay, Hagen Telg

content.description: Short, 5.9 thin hands/hands--A fine intro to the area or warmup. Hand jam up the crack to a tricky, steep bit of thin hands about halfway up. A nice sloping ledge allows for a break before the very short bit of hands to the anchors.
content.protection: #1 and #2 camalots to rap hangers anchor.
content.location: Just right of the golden face in the small alcove.

content.description: This short but pretty looking wide crack climbs quite well.. It starts out at just about six inches and quickly gets wider, which makes laybacking about the best option, despite its slight overhang. A straight in OW ascent would be an exercise in proud technique.
content.protection: Three bolts and one 0.5 or  0.75 behind a wedged block up high.
content.location: Just left of Tuning Fork on the same ledge.

content.description:
Climb a wide start up to a roof.  Pull left around the roof. 

  More fun than it looks, I swear!
content.location: Just around the corner to east of the main Hinterlands area.  Look for a wide start to a big roof block.

content.description: Thin hands in a corner for almost the entire route. Starts with powerful laybacking or thin hands jamming if that's your thing. A pod near the middle allows for a no-hands rest before another strenuous thin hands section. Eases a bit at the top.
content.protection: Heavy on the 0.75 and #1 camalots. 0.5 near the top. A #4 BD goes nicely just above the big pod halfway up.
content.location: Just left of Anal Intruder. Thin hand crack in a longer corner.

content.description:
An interesting, perhaps slightly spooky, varied climb. Big hands crack at the start leads to a weird and hollow flake feature, the Deathly Hollow (overly dramatic!) where one can hand jam next to but also reach around the back of. It jams well but don't place protection next to it (I'd like to add a bolt here to help keep the flake from busting and better protect the section.)  

  Move up to a block and some finger crack climbing to a good stance. A short section of thin hands leads to the anchor.
content.protection: Single rack from .3 to #3 camalots. Doubles from .5 to #1.
content.location: On the right side of the area, right of a wide chimney/gully. The hollow flake feature is pretty obvious.

climbs.name: Chosspector Gulch
climbs.fa: Forest Altherr, Brandon Gabel, Mike Wheat

content.description: A blocky buttress and dihedral system offering variety stemming, finger-locks and a small crux roof. The roof has a crack left and right of it. There are some chossy flakes over the roof avoided carefully by the left or right crack. The left crack has some dirt in it. The right crack tempts you to grab loose flakes. The right crack is easier. The left crack offers up classic tight hands to finger locks on steep. The main ledge in the lower-middle of the route unfortunately breaks the route up and offers a small cactus to avoid. Finish at a stance and two bolt chain anchor under the summit block roof.
content.protection: Standard rack of cams. Some extra small cams and/or a few small nuts. Slings to control rope drag.
content.location: Left, next to and around the outside corner from Rumo. Climbers left side of Hinterlands.

climbs.name: Anal Intruder
climbs.fa: Hagen Telg, Claudia Ihm  FFA: Josh Smith

content.description:
If you like flaring off-width and squeeze chimneys, then Nick Rivers has a gift for you.

  Anal Intruder is the obvious offwidth at the Hinterlands. Get into it, work up to "the intruder" block, swing out and into fists/wide hand crack to a ledge. Clip a bolt (drilled on lead during FA) high on the face and grunt up the squeeze to the anchors.
content.protection: #5, #4s, #3, #2 camalot and a draw/sling for the high bolt.
content.location: To the right of Goodbye Germany.

climbs.name: An American, a German and a Kiwi Walked Into a Bar...
climbs.fa: Hagen Telg, Andrew Sykes, Jason Halladay

content.description: Surprisingly accessible and fun wide climbing leads to a chimney in an alcove. Stem and chimney up easy, featured rock for ten feet to the wide crack and the first gear, a #6 camalot. Squirm up the offset wide crack for another ten feet to a wedged chockstone. You can get gear around the chockstone. A few more feet of wide climbing takes you to the alcove and chimney above. Easy but unprotected chimneying gets you out of the alcove and to the anchors.
content.protection: Very minimal rack. #6 camalot, #2 camalot (or a big sling around wedged chockstone.) Cold shut anchors at top.
content.location: Obvious, somewhat unappealing-looking (yet quite fun) wide crack to chimney left of the golden face.

content.description: Quality, short and stout. Thin hands to hands with a cruxy bulge down low in a tight corner. Step right to the anchor. Prost!
content.location: In the back corner of The Hinterlands. If one wants to TR the route, the anchor can be reached from lowering off Goodbye Germany.

pathTokens: Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags

content.description:
A compact cragging area with cracks of all sizes and variety. The routes are on the short side, 70 feet or less, with a good variety making for a nice introduction to Capulin climbing. Despite the name, the area has one of the shorter approaches in Capulin but that is not to say it's an easy approach...one must still descend all the way down to the canyon and still do the energy-sapping hike out at the end of the day.  

  The Hinterlands are in a south-facing corner and, like nearly all of the Capulin climbing, bakes in the sun. But because it's a corner the routes on the right side of the area are shaded for a bit in the morning and the routes on the left side shaded in the afternoon.
